channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Have to upgrade jackson databind to 2.9.9.2.

  • (edit) tika-parent/pom.xml

I still have these when running the versions plugin:

com.drewnoakes:metadata-extractor ................... 2.11.0 -> 2.12.0
com.pff:java-libpst ................................... 0.8.1 -> 0.9.3
edu.ucar:grib ........................................ 4.5.5 -> 8.0.29

The second one has a text that this shouldn't be updated, but the other ones don't.

I tested updating the first one, I had to update another dependency as well (adobe xmpcore), lots of code (add "internal" to the "com.adobe.internal.xmp.*" imports) but at the end it built successfully.

Should this be included

  • in this release
  • in the next one
  • not at all
    ?

tilman, thank you for raising these items for discussion.

1. com.pff:java-libpst – I didn't upgrade that because of this: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TIKA-2546?page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel&focusedCommentId=16324009#comment-16324009

cc lfcnassif

2. metadata-extractor – I didn't upgrade that because of the change in namespace, and I was worried that'd break code for people using our xmp module. I asked privately if we could get anyone at Adobe to release their xmp module without the internal namespace. I haven't heard anything back. If anyone knows anyone at Adobe who would be willing to do this, please, please do ask.

I was wondering if we could shade+relocate that library in the near term to get rid of the internal. namespace. Thoughts?

3. edu.ucar:grib – I didn't upgrade that because the jump in major version # frightened me. I think I tried to upgrade it earlier, and I would have had do redo a bunch of our code...this could be a faulty memory.

So, my preference would be to put off 1) until libpst is fixed, 2) until we have success with shade+relocating or another solution and 3) until someone who knows that library can upgrade our code.

What do you and fellow devs think?
I agree and suggest to put this (or just a reference to this issue) in the pom file. I can't comment about shading because I have never done it.
Will do. Thank you, again!

TIKA-2925 – improve documentation to explain decision not to upgrade (tallison: https://github.com/apache/tika/commit/85cd36d5f16e27bd5ec222ff18dcb3035c5f502d)

  • (edit) tika-parsers/pom.xml

SUCCESS: Integrated in Jenkins build Tika-trunk #1754 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/Tika-trunk/1754/)
TIKA-2925 – improve documentation to explain decision not to upgrade (tallison: https://github.com/apache/tika/commit/6346eeb0f41e3fc35afdae09ccab0e0230be5670)

  • (edit) tika-parsers/pom.xml

Hi tallison,

Just tested java-libpst-0.9.4. It still has the same critical bug reported on https://github.com/rjohnsondev/java-libpst/issues/60

But, I got a simple idea right now. We can upgrade the lib and update PSTParser to check the PST/OST file version with pstFile.getPSTFileType(). If it is equal to PSTFile.PST_TYPE_2013_UNICODE, we can throw an Exception to let the user know that the library does not handle those files correctly and misses lots of emails silently.

What do you think?

Currently I have an alternative parser that uses pffexport command line tool (https://github.com/libyal/libpff) and I run it when java-libpst fails. Not sure if parsers based on command line tools are good to integrate into Tika...

This sounds good. Does our current version of libpst handle PSTFile.PST_TYPE_2013_UNICODE correctly?

Adding a parser for libpff along the lines of Tesseract would make sense, I think...at some point. Do we have a sense of how common those PST types are? Does libpff handle other types of PST/OST that libpst is failing on?

Thank you lfcnassif for looking into this!

No, our current version just throws an exception when PSTFile.PST_TYPE_2013_UNICODE is found. That is the behaviour I would like to keep while java-libpst is not fixed, instead of processing PST_TYPE_2013_UNICODE and silently missing thousands of emails.

At least for my use case, processing desktop files, PST/OST files are very common.

java-libpst was based on documentation built by reverse enginnering made by libpff author. As far as I know, libpff support for OST 2013 files is great. And it recovers deleted emails too, very valuable for my organization.
Great.  As long as we aren't losing anything (or too much), let's do it!  Thank you, again!
